pull.title: optimization: Speed up Base58 conversion through intermediary Base56 conversion by 300%
pull.body:
Continuing the base conversion optimizations, started in [TryParseHex](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/29458).

To mitigate the quadratic complexity inherent in the sequential byte division of the Base58 encoding process, this update aggregates characters into groups of 7, fitting them into 64-bit long integers.
This refinement utilizes the inherent efficiency of native division and modulo operations on 64-bit architectures, significantly optimizing computational overhead.
The benchmarks indicate a 3x speedup for `Base58CheckEncode` and `Base58Encode`:

make && ./src/bench/bench_bitcoin --filter=Base58Encode --min-time=1000
Before:
```
|             ns/byte |              byte/s |    err% |     total | benchmark
|--------------------:|--------------------:|--------:|----------:|:----------
|               59.27 |       16,872,442.54 |    0.2% |      1.10 | `Base58Encode`
|               59.09 |       16,923,588.35 |    0.1% |      1.10 | `Base58Encode`
|               59.15 |       16,906,104.83 |    0.3% |      1.11 | `Base58Encode`
```
After:
```
|             ns/byte |              byte/s |    err% |     total | benchmark
|--------------------:|--------------------:|--------:|----------:|:----------
|               19.60 |       51,030,357.30 |    0.1% |      1.06 | `Base58Encode`
|               19.59 |       51,043,935.83 |    0.1% |      1.06 | `Base58Encode`
|               19.59 |       51,041,953.60 |    0.1% |      1.06 | `Base58Encode`
```

make && ./src/bench/bench_bitcoin --filter=Base58CheckEncode --min-time=1000
Before:
```
|             ns/byte |              byte/s |    err% |     total | benchmark
|--------------------:|--------------------:|--------:|----------:|:----------
|               79.93 |       12,511,576.75 |    0.4% |      1.10 | `Base58CheckEncode`
|               79.49 |       12,580,136.21 |    0.1% |      1.10 | `Base58CheckEncode`
|               79.65 |       12,554,785.16 |    0.1% |      1.10 | `Base58CheckEncode`
```
After:
```
|             ns/byte |              byte/s |    err% |     total | benchmark
|--------------------:|--------------------:|--------:|----------:|:----------
|               26.35 |       37,952,933.55 |    0.2% |      1.08 | `Base58CheckEncode`
|               26.43 |       37,838,264.59 |    0.2% |      1.08 | `Base58CheckEncode`
|               26.35 |       37,946,567.63 |    0.1% |      1.08 | `Base58CheckEncode`
```

Please review it [commit-by-commit](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/29473/commits) for extra context.

documentation.

Possibly this is due to a silent merge conflict (the changes in this pull request being
incompatible with the current code in the target branch). If so, make sure to rebase on the latest
commit of the target branch.

Leave a comment here, if you need help tracking down a confusing failure.

<sub>Debug: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/runs/21941361780</sub>

events.message: Add a few more corner cases to the base58 test suite
Unify size estimations in Base58 encoding/decoding

Remove redundant zero-skipping logic in Base58 encode/decode

This patch removes unnecessary iterations over initial zero bytes in the Base58 encoding and decoding processes.

Refactor base58 encoding for future optimizations

Introduced a `clone` function to simplify the base58 encoding process, creating an `inputClone` subvector from the input without leading zeros. This structural change, while temporarily reducing execution speed due to the larger size of `inputClone` versus the original `b58` buffer, is a strategic step towards the base56 bulking, done in the next commit.

Enhance base58 conversion through intermediary base56 grouping

To mitigate the quadratic complexity inherent in the sequential byte division of the Base58 encoding process, this update aggregates characters into groups of 7, fitting them into 64-bit long integers.
This refinement utilizes the inherent efficiency of native division and modulo operations on 64-bit architectures, significantly optimizing computational overhead.
The benchmarks indicate an almost 2-3x speedup for `Base58CheckEncode` and `Base58Encode`:

make && ./src/bench/bench_bitcoin --filter=Base58Encode --min-time=1000
Before:
```
|             ns/byte |              byte/s |    err% |     total | benchmark
|--------------------:|--------------------:|--------:|----------:|:----------
|               59.27 |       16,872,442.54 |    0.2% |      1.10 | `Base58Encode`
|               59.09 |       16,923,588.35 |    0.1% |      1.10 | `Base58Encode`
|               59.15 |       16,906,104.83 |    0.3% |      1.11 | `Base58Encode`
```
After:
```
|             ns/byte |              byte/s |    err% |     total | benchmark
|--------------------:|--------------------:|--------:|----------:|:----------
|               19.60 |       51,030,357.30 |    0.1% |      1.06 | `Base58Encode`
|               19.59 |       51,043,935.83 |    0.1% |      1.06 | `Base58Encode`
|               19.59 |       51,041,953.60 |    0.1% |      1.06 | `Base58Encode`
```

make && ./src/bench/bench_bitcoin --filter=Base58CheckEncode --min-time=1000
Before:
```
|             ns/byte |              byte/s |    err% |     total | benchmark
|--------------------:|--------------------:|--------:|----------:|:----------
|               79.93 |       12,511,576.75 |    0.4% |      1.10 | `Base58CheckEncode`
|               79.49 |       12,580,136.21 |    0.1% |      1.10 | `Base58CheckEncode`
|               79.65 |       12,554,785.16 |    0.1% |      1.10 | `Base58CheckEncode`
```
After:
```
|             ns/byte |              byte/s |    err% |     total | benchmark
|--------------------:|--------------------:|--------:|----------:|:----------
|               26.35 |       37,952,933.55 |    0.2% |      1.08 | `Base58CheckEncode`
|               26.43 |       37,838,264.59 |    0.2% |      1.08 | `Base58CheckEncode`
|               26.35 |       37,946,567.63 |    0.1% |      1.08 | `Base58CheckEncode`
```
Apply code conventions to modified code areas

comments.body: we could use 1024 here for fast division - not sure it's worth the change
probably left over from a previous refactoring, there's no skipping here anymore
we're collecting the zeros in the beginning, this was always false
slightly slower but a lot simpler - preparing the scene for the main commit
unify the constants in a separate commit to leave the campground cleaner than I found it
271F35A0 is 58^5 - and -2, -1, and +1 to make sure boundaries are handled correctly
convert to base56 quickly before converting to base58 to minimize the inner quadratic loop
Looks like you are unintentionally aliasing `GROUP_SIZE` as both a constant and this argument.
Hah, indeed, last minute refactoring, thanks!
convert to base56 quickly before converting to base58 to minimize the inner quadratic loop
converting from base(256) to base(256^7) speeds up processing since we can do actual division and modulo on the resulting int64

This construct with the two nested loops is not evident. Maybe some comment would be useful. The inner loop does not depend on the value of `i`. Is it repeated for as long as all `inputAsLongs` elements are reduced to 0?
Fantastic comment, the internal loop should skip the leading zeros, indeed.
start division and next digit calculation from the biggest non-zero chunk
